head.title: Powerful Delbarton Trails at Halftime for a Change, and Has to Rally to Win

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New York

hedline.hl1: Powerful Delbarton Trails at Halftime for a Change, and Has to Rally to Win

abstract.p: Article discusses New York City metropolitan area high school football results (M)

block.p: For two seasons, the Delbarton Green Wave had cruised into its locker room each week with a comfortable halftime lead.
Bishop Francis, an unranked team from East Orange, N.J., ended that streak yesterday, taking advantage of four Delbarton mistakes to jump to a 13-point halftime advantage.
For two seasons, the Delbarton Green Wave had cruised into its locker room each week with a comfortable halftime lead.
Bishop Francis, an unranked team from East Orange, N.J., ended that streak yesterday, taking advantage of four Delbarton mistakes to jump to a 13-point halftime advantage.

But Delbarton, New Jersey's second-ranked team, scored three consecutive touchdowns in the second half to win, 28-20, despite playing without its starting quarterback (Jeff Parros) and star receiver (Wes Swackhamer).

Delbarton, of Morris County, N.J., benefited from two touchdowns in the fourth quarter by Sean Farrell. The first score by Farrell, a senior tailback, was a 2-yard run, capping a 12-play, 86-yard drive. Farrell recovered the ensuing onside kick, and five plays later, he scored from 4 yards out. Farrell finished with 117 yards on 12 carries.
Delbarton's other touchdowns were scored by Raffael DeLuca, on a 3-yard run in the first quarter, and Geoff Close's 8-yard run in the third.

Bishop Francis' scores came on Corey Cooper's 88-yard kickoff return in the first quarter; Calif Harris's 3-yard run in the second quarter (set up by a blocked punt); and Anthony Bailey's 1-yard dive (set up by an interception) in the second quarter.

Delbarton's defense kept Bishop Francis out of the end zone in the second half largerly because of the stellar play of the junior linebacker Gavin Weeks, who registered 7 of his 11 tackles and a sack in the fourth quarter.
Elsewhere in New Jersey, Bergen Catholic (4-0), the third-rated team in the state, kept its undefeated season alive by defeating Paramus Catholic, 29-20.

Joe Sandberg (19 carries for 124 yards) and Andrew Stuerzel (16 carries for 68 yards) rushed for a touchdown apiece and Jeff Sticco scored twice to pace the Crusaders. Chris Hanly, a sophomore, kicked a 32-yard field goal with 1 minute 40 seconds remaining to ice the game.

For Paramus Catholic (1-3), James O'Leary, a sophomore quarterback, completed 22 of 45 for 218 yards and 3 touchdowns. O'Leary's scoring passes were to Paul Santiago, Mike Sumulikoski and Eddie Smith.

Thomas Zydel, Bergen Catholic's senior quarterback, completed 7 of 9 passes for 90 yards. Bergen Catholic's rushing attack produced 253 yards, while Paramus Catholic's ground game was held to 11 yards.
Bergen Catholic plays at home against Bloomfield (3-0) next Saturday.
On Friday night, Paterson Catholic (4-0) ended Glen Rock's 26-game winning streak, 14-10.

Reggie Brown, a senior fullback, ran 34 times for 205 yards and a touchdown to help Paterson Catholic end Glen Rock's impressive run, which began in its second game in 1998. Glen Rock (3-1) had not lost to Paterson Catholic since 1993.

But with Brown leading the offense and lineman Davon Clark leading the defense, Paterson Catholic avenged its only loss of last year. Clark had quite a day as he piled up 3 sacks, 2 tipped passes and an interception at the Glen Rock 10-yard line.
Glen Rock did not go quietly however. Glen Rock's Craig Agnello returned a kickoff 90 yards for a touchdown in the second half that cut the deficit to 20-14.

On Paterson Catholic's next possession, Glen Rock got an interception from Joe Barron with a little less than five minutes left in the game. Glen Rock's chances were ended, however, when safety Nygel McGuire intercepted a pass and Paterson Catholic ran out the clock.
C.H.S.F.L.
In a battle of Catholic High School Football League Bronx rivals, FORDHAM PREP (3-1) defeated MOUNT ST. MICHAEL (2-1), 27-7.

Matt Rinklin, a senior, led the way for Fordham Prep, completing 18 of 29 passes for 239 yards and 2 touchdowns. Both touchdown passes were to David Bailey, who had 7 catches for 178 yards. Bailey also intercepted a pass and ran it back 41 yards for a touchdown. The senior linebacker Michael Sangobowale anchored the defense with four tackles and two sacks.
PREPS

Mike Francour (10 of 17 for 185 yards) hooked up with Steve Radkovich (six catches for 122 yards) on two scoring plays as CHESHIRE ACADEMY (1-1) cruised to a 30-22 victory over NEW YORK MILITARY ACADEMY (0-3). Jim Walsh of New York Military Academy ran for two touchdowns and threw for another.
SALISBURY (2-0) rocked host CANTERBURY, 41-7. Dennis Hicks rushed for 91 yards on 19 carries for Canterbury (1-1).

On Friday night, Danny Skelly, a senior tailback, scored three short touchdowns -- two on the ground and one by air -- to help RIVERDALE (3-0) to a 29-20 victory over NAZARETH (2-2). Skelly also recorded 11 tackles as an inside linebacker. Joe Bernard (12 carries for 71 yards) contributed a 23-yard touchdown run in the victory.
HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL
